title: 103_hr113
content: The "Buy American Motor Vehicles Act of 1993" aims to boost economic growth by offering a temporary tax credit to encourage the purchase of new domestic passenger vehicles. This credit can be assigned by the purchaser in exchange for a reduction in the vehicle's purchase price. The "Buy American Motor Vehicles Act of 1993" provides a tax credit for individuals purchasing new domestic passenger vehicles. The credit amount is based on the applicable percentage of the vehicle's purchase price, with limits set for different calendar years. The maximum credit allowed varies depending on the taxable year. Additionally, the credit can be assigned by the purchaser as per regulations set by the Secretary. The tax credit for purchasing new domestic passenger vehicles allows individuals to assign the credit to the dealer or manufacturer in exchange for a purchase price reduction. The credit amount is based on the vehicle's purchase price and can be used against the manufacturer's tax liability. A new domestic passenger vehicle is defined as a passenger vehicle purchased in the 1st retail sale. The term 'domestic vehicle' refers to a vehicle produced by a domestic manufacturer in the US or Canada, with specific labeling requirements regarding its eligibility for tax credits. The term 'domestic vehicle manufacturer' refers to a manufacturer of motor vehicles with facilities in the US that utilize parts from domestic manufacturers. The term 'domestic parts manufacturer' refers to a manufacturer of motor vehicle parts with facilities in the US or Canada, utilizing parts from domestic manufacturers. The term 'related source' refers to a natural person who is a citizen of Japan or a corporation that is affiliated with the production of motor vehicle parts, with restrictions on the use of materials from related sources not exceeding 25 percent of total production value. The term 'related source' includes natural persons who are citizens of Japan or corporations owned or controlled by Japanese citizens. Ownership or control is defined as holding at least 50 percent of the capital structure in the case of a corporation. The term 'own or control' means holding at least 50 percent of the capital structure in a corporation, or holding interests representing at least 50 percent of the capital structure in any other legal entity. A domestic parts manufacturer is affiliated with a related source if the related source holds at least 2.5 percent but less than 50 percent of the capital structure. The term 'own or control' means holding 50 percent of the capital structure in a corporation or at least 2.5 percent but less than 50 percent in any other legal entity. Purchase price and value definitions apply to materials and components used in motor vehicle parts production. The cost of materials and components for motor vehicles is determined for manufacturers, including related sources. The term 'United States' includes Puerto Rico and US possessions. Regulations will be prescribed within 60 days to prevent avoidance of limitations. This section does not apply to vehicles purchased after December 31, 1994. The amendments made by this section apply to vehicles purchased after December 31, 1992.
